title: 'If it's a good idea, you'll get the money'
text:
Terracini isn’t being hypothetical. He recalls his first executive meeting at this office in October of 2009 – a year in which the company would ultimately lose $900,000 – being to discuss a proposal for making every role at OA part-time.

“That would have been catastrophic. There was a lot of blame on the global financial crisis at the time, but the reality was the industry had been complacent for too long,” he says. “The time of [supergroup] The Three Tenors, which gave opera a huge financial boost, had passed and there needed to be something new to excite people again.”

Ring of truth

Terracini, whose populist gestures while running the Brisbane Festival included bringing former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev to town, immediately began working on three such excitements.

First, he got OA to produce Wagner’s mammoth, 15-hour The Ring Cycle for the first time, premiering it in Melbourne in 2013. “Any opera company that purports to any kind of international reputation has to be doing The Ring,” he says.

What might have seemed liked madness for a cash-strapped company has, in a subsequent Sydney production with a third to follow in Brisbane next year, become something of a cash cow.

Selling the vision

Terracini’s next vision back in 2009 – an opera staged on Sydney Harbour – required another big cheque-writer. He didn’t even have an appointment to meet Japanese businessman and philanthropist Haruhisa Handa, but he flew to Tokyo anyway.

Opera Australia staged La Traviata on Sydney Harbour in 2012; it's set for a return next year.

“I learnt from my festival days that if it’s a good idea, you will get the money,” Terracini says. “I knew that Handa had studied opera in his youth and cared about connecting more people to the artform. We ended up getting twice as much as what I’d told our chief financial officer we were aiming for.”

Advertisement

Handa Opera On Sydney Harbour (HOSH) has been staged eight times, the season attracting about 50,000 people a year, three-quarters of whom have never attended an indoor opera. Terracini claims about a quarter of those people now go on to do so.

Terracini’s musical bid for the masses paid immediate dividends when 2014’s The King & I saw OA’s sales revenue jump 27 per cent.

“The subscribers hated HOSH at first; it used amplification, it took resources from mainstage opera and so on, but now no one cares,” Terracini says. “People buy tickets to HOSH before they even know what’s on, and it’s helped us fund a lot of less-popular operas we’d never have produced otherwise.”

But Terracini’s greatest and most controversial money spinner was his attempt to reach those resistant even to HOSH, by staging a musical each year. “If we’re receiving money from the government – and that’s where

$26 million of the $115 million we turned over last year came from – then it’s our duty to play to as many people as possible,” he says.

Terracini’s musical bid for the masses paid immediate dividends when 2014’s The King & I saw OA’s sales revenue jump 27 per cent, as the Rodgers & Hammerstein chestnut broke box-office records at the Sydney Opera House.

Italian Mezzo Soprano, Josè Maria Lo Monaco performed the role of Carmen for the 2017 Handa Opera on Sydney Harbour. James Brickwood

It’s a record only bested since by OA’s production of another musical, My Fair Lady directed by Dame Julie Andrews, which single-handedly saw the company through that otherwise lean 2017. However the move into musicals, to which trained operatic voices often aren’t suited, initially meant a reduction in the number of traditional operas staged by OA.

Something had to give, and Terracini made what he admits has been the hardest decision of his tenure – moving the company’s singers from full-time contracts onto performance-based fees.

The sacking of local singers caused an uproar, and by 2014 had nudged the opera-loving then-arts minister George Brandis into holding a national review of the artform. The review recommended that no government funding go into “significant commercial activities” like HOSH or musicals, and that companies be fined $200,000 if they didn’t cast local singers in at least 80 per cent of principal lead roles.

Meanwhile, Terracini defends his heavy use of international singers, like superstar German tenor Jonas Kaufmann, as a way of funding the development of local talent.

Advertisement

“The response to Jonas, the best in the world at what he does, was absolutely euphoric when we had him here this year. He connects to people like Pavarotti used to and that’s what we need to get people back to the opera,” he says.

Terracini sees the company’s ability to keep performing the classic French, Italian and Mozartian operas at a world-class standard, and increasingly with Millennial-attracting digital technology, as the most important part of his legacy.

Lyndon Terracini who plays the mercenary in Paul Grabowsky's opera, The Mercenary.

“People say it’s brave to do Ghost Sonata,” he says, referring to the cerebral August Strindberg piece OA just staged for 1000-odd punters at its scenery workshop, starring former Wagga Wagga heavy metal singer Shanul Sharma. “But what’s really brave is sticking to your guns and excelling at the core repertoire.”

As for when the line will be ruled under that legacy, Terracini says he is “in discussions” with the board about his future after 2021. He won’t elaborate, but judging from his comments to a Brisbane newspaper while contemplating his third festival there in 2006, it’s a fair bet he’ll have overseen his final Tosca before the decade is out.

“Some people are happy to stay for 20 years but, ultimately, I don’t think that’s healthy for an organisation,” he told the Courier-Mail at the time.

Terracini’s advice to his successor is to take things a little easier.

“In the beginning I pushed too hard,” says the man who admits to having no hobbies outside of work, and chats to patrons while attending OA performances most nights. “At a festival, you’ve got a year to produce, but a major opera company is a big ship to turn around. It’s only in the last couple of years that I feel we’ve realised our potential – it took me 10 years to get to where I wanted to in five.”
description: Artistic director Lyndon Terracini has kept Opera Australia on song financially but not everyone is a fan.
